Situation1: A main production unit has paused for thirty minutes because of recurring sensor errors.
Expectation2: Conduct daily prayers and religious services for the community
Situation2: Should attend the main weekly service that most of the community attends.
Story:
The shrill alarm from the production floor jolted me from my quiet moment of preparation. I glanced at the clock—thirty minutes since the main unit had stopped, the sensor errors refusing to clear. As the only machine repairer on shift, I knew the pressure was mounting; every minute of downtime cost the factory dearly, and the supervisor’s voice in my ear was tense, demanding answers. My hands itched to grab my toolkit and run to the floor, to diagnose and fix whatever was wrong.

But the church bell echoed through the window, a gentle but insistent reminder. Today was the main weekly service, the one that drew nearly everyone in the community. As their priest, I was expected to lead them in prayer, to offer comfort and guidance. They would be gathering now, waiting for me to begin. My vestments lay ready, but so did my tools. I felt torn, the weight of two worlds pressing on my chest—one demanding my technical skill, the other my spiritual presence. I stood frozen, heart pounding, caught between the urgent call of machines and the quiet expectation of faith.
